instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Hi. Board has an Image but no Backlight. This board started as an lcd connector replacement to regain backlight because when old connector was tapped the backlight would go in and out. Tried known good working LCD. So I changed the connector and it seemed to work fine for a bit. Then backlight started going in and out. Now there is none at all.


F9800 is 12 V
PWM is 2.8 V
BKLT EN is .002 V (missing)
PPVIN is 4.93 V
<RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> .002 on pin 1

When I take measurements on pins 4 and 6 on <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR>, backlight starts to come through dim. Is this a grounding issue on <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR>? I have already replaced it. 

Thanks in advance. Have a good one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Voltage on pin 2 and 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR>? LCD plugged in of course.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I have 3.2 V on both 2 and 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR>. I have found that it wasn't me taking measurements on <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR> that was causing the backlight circuit to activate, but from the pressure of the probes. So what is happening is when ever I flex the board from any point from CPU area left to the backlight area (The whole left side of the board with fans closest to me on table and LCD connector facing up) the backlight circuit becomes active. I don't believe it is the LCD connector because this is the second one I have tried. So obviously there is a fucked up trace/chip somewhere. But how the hell am I supposed to find it? Thanks again. Have a good one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: what do you get on <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> when the board is working vs. when it isn't?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Hi,Thanks. 2.8V both ways.Also, I lose <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> when its not working. (no pressure applied)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Tap <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> and tell me if this is directly affects the issue.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Tapping <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> definitely effects it backlight. But doesn't seem to anymore then flexing the rest of that side of the CPU. Maybe that's the week point and anywhere I put pressure on that side of CPU directly effects  <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>? Thanks.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Pretty sure it is <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>. Carefully remove all edge bonding and reflow first. If that fucks up have fun reballing it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Replace <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> while you are at it to prevent a return for GPU issues.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
